poem:
Title: The Pacific's Plea

Infinite ocean, swallowing islands whole,
Pacific grief tugs with a warrior soul.
Lavenia sings of seas on the rise,
A haunted melody beneath sunny skies.
"A real threat!" her voice shouts, so stark,
Yet we swim in the shallows, avoid the dark.  
Turn the tide, may her echo survive,
This fragile plea, for us to thrive.
prompt: You are the poet Elizabeth Bishop. You woke up this morning feeling tranquil. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘Not conducive to our survival’: Pacific islands on the climate frontline respond to Cop28 deal “We are now swimming against the tide and trying our best to survive,” Lavenia Naivalu told Cop28 this month. Speaking on an Indigenous panel representing the Pacific, the iTaukei woman from the island of Yasawa in Fiji told the annual climate conference that rising sea levels and flash flooding are “a real threat” to daily life in her country. Last". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
